dt: {bc}the act of postponing, hindering, or causing something to occur more slowly than normal {bc}the state of being {d_link|delayed|delay:2}
{bc}the time during which something is delayed

shortdef: the act of postponing, hindering, or causing something to occur more slowly than normal : the state of being delayed
the time during which something is delayed

dt.t: They're {wi}delaying{/wi} marriage or, increasingly, not getting married at all …

dt: {bc}to stop, detain, or hinder for a time

dt.t: the mails were {wi}delayed{/wi} by heavy snows
… issued executive orders {wi}delaying{/wi} the release of records from Ronald Reagan's administration …

dt: {bc}to cause to be slower or to occur more slowly than normal

dt.t: … a drug that not only can extend life by {wi}delaying{/wi} the onset of aging-related diseases …
This offer ends soon, so don't {wi}delay{/wi}.

pt: {sc}delay{/sc} {sc}retard{/sc} {sc}slow{/sc} {sc}slacken{/sc} {sc}detain{/sc} mean to cause to be late or behind in movement or progress. {sc}delay{/sc} implies a holding back, usually by interference, from completion or arrival.
{sc}retard{/sc} suggests reduction of speed without actual stopping.
{sc}slow{/sc} and {sc}slacken{/sc} also imply a reduction of speed, {sc}slow{/sc} often suggesting deliberate intention
, {sc}slacken{/sc} an easing up or relaxing of power or effort.

pt.t: on hot days runners {it}slacken{/it} their pace

pt: {sc}detain{/sc} implies a holding back beyond a reasonable or appointed time.

{sc}delay{/sc} {sc}procrastinate{/sc} {sc}lag{/sc} {sc}loiter{/sc} {sc}dawdle{/sc} {sc}dally{/sc} mean to move or act slowly so as to fall behind. {sc}delay{/sc} usually implies a putting off of something (such as a beginning or departure).
{sc}procrastinate{/sc} implies blameworthy delay especially through laziness or apathy.
{sc}lag{/sc} implies failure to maintain a speed set by others.
{sc}loiter{/sc} and {sc}dawdle{/sc} imply delay while in progress, especially in walking, but {sc}dawdle{/sc} more clearly suggests an aimless wasting of time.

pt.t: children {it}dawdling{/it} on their way home from school

pt: {sc}dally{/sc} suggests delay through trifling or vacillation when promptness is necessary.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}delaier{/it}, from {it}de-{/it} + {it}laier{/it} to leave, from {it}lai-{/it}, present and future stem of {it}lesser, laisser{/it} to leave, from Latin {it}laxare{/it} to slacken, from {it}laxus{/it} loose {ma}{mat|slack|}{/ma}
shortdef: to stop, detain, or hinder for a time
to cause to be slower or to occur more slowly than normal

dt.t: The roof must be repaired {it}without delay{/it}.

dt: {bc}something that is done in order to delay a decision, an occurrence, etc.

shortdef: something that is done in order to delay a decision, an occurrence, etc.
